title: 115_s625
content: The Act is titled the "Foreign Agents Registration Modernization and Enforcement Act." It amends the Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938 by adding civil investigative demand authority. Sec. 8 of the "Foreign Agents Registration Modernization and Enforcement Act" grants the Attorney General the authority to demand the production of relevant documentary material from individuals or enterprises before initiating legal proceedings. The demand must specify the nature of the alleged violation, describe the required material, and state that it is immediately returnable. The Attorney General has the authority to demand the production of relevant documentary material from individuals or enterprises before legal proceedings. The demand must specify the alleged violation, describe the required material, and identify the custodian for inspection. The demand may not contain unreasonable requirements or demand privileged documentary evidence. SEC. 3. INFORMATIONAL MATERIALS. The Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938 is amended to include a definition of "informational materials" as any form of information published through various means. Additionally, the Act is amended to include electronic mail and social media as forms of communication in the United States. The Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938 is amended to include social media and electronic mail as forms of communication in the United States. Foreign agents may omit disclosure in individual social media posts on behalf of a foreign principal. The Foreign Agents Registration Act of 1938 now includes social media and electronic mail as forms of communication in the United States. Social media transmissions on behalf of a foreign principal must include a statement indicating the account is operated by the foreign agent and additional information is on file with the Department of Justice in Washington, D.C. Informational materials disseminated by a foreign agent exempt from registration do not need to be filed under this subsection. SEC. 4. FEES. The Department of Justice will collect fees to cover expenses of the Registration Unit under the Foreign Agents Registration Act. The Act is amended to include fees for necessary expenses. The Attorney General will establish a registration fee to cover expenses of the Registration Unit under the Foreign Agents Registration Act. The fees will be part of the initial filing requirement and credited to the appropriation for this purpose. Additionally, reports to Congress will be required as outlined in the Act. The Assistant Attorney General for National Security will submit a semiannual report to Congress on the administration of the Foreign Agents Registration Act, including registrations filed, political propaganda disseminated by foreign agents, investigations initiated, and referrals for prosecution.
